articles.headline: Jets, Horses and Bribes: How a Venezuelan Official Became a Billionaire as His Country Crumbled
articles.snippet: Alejandro Andrade, a former treasurer in Venezuela’s Socialist government, will be sentenced next week after pleading guilty to receiving more than $1 billion in bribes.
articles.abstract: Alejandro Andrade, a former treasurer in Venezuela’s Socialist government, will be sentenced next week after pleading guilty to receiving more than $1 billion in bribes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The opulent lifestyle of the Andrade family was as spectacular as the economic collapse of the country they left behind.

articles.headline: South Korea Loves Plastic Surgery and Makeup. Some Women Want to Change That.
articles.snippet: Gender inequality and the global #MeToo movement have fueled “Escape the Corset,” a campaign to cast off the country’s rigid beauty standards.
articles.abstract: Gender inequality and the global #MeToo movement have fueled “Escape the Corset,” a campaign to cast off the country’s rigid beauty standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Kim Ji-yeon knew she wanted plastic surgery when she was 7. For the next 13 years, she destroyed photos of herself until her parents paid for double jaw surgery, a procedure that requires breaking the jaw to realign it.

articles.headline: A Winter-Coat Heavyweight Gives Trump’s Trade War the Cold Shoulder
articles.snippet: Columbia Sportswear has worked around tariffs for decades — and it says the president’s new wave of levies will not bring jobs back to America.
articles.abstract: Columbia Sportswear has worked around tariffs for decades — and it says the president’s new wave of levies will not bring jobs back to America.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Columbia Sportswear has spent years designing ski jackets and hiking boots to withstand the elements: wind, rain, snow and, increasingly, tariffs.

articles.headline: The Website That Shows How a Free Press Can Die
articles.snippet: Origo was a popular, independent news outlet that made trouble for Hungary’s far-right leader, Viktor Orban. Relentless pressure changed all that.
articles.abstract: Origo was a popular, independent news outlet that made trouble for Hungary’s far-right leader, Viktor Orban. Relentless pressure changed all that.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUDAPEST — Hungary’s leading news website, Origo, had a juicy scoop: A top aide to the far-right prime minister, Viktor Orban, had used state money to pay for sizable but unexplained expenses during secret foreign trips. The story embarrassed Mr. Orban and was a reminder that his country still had an independent press.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Benjamin Novak

articles.headline: Across South, Democrats Who Speak Boldly Risk Alienating Rural White Voters
articles.snippet: Mike Espy, the Democratic nominee in the Mississippi Senate election Tuesday, has had to choose between satisfying African-Americans and white liberals or driving away conservative-leaning voters.
articles.abstract: Mike Espy, the Democratic nominee in the Mississippi Senate election Tuesday, has had to choose between satisfying African-Americans and white liberals or driving away conservative-leaning voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: JACKSON, Miss. — When Mike Espy, the Democrat challenging Senator Cindy Hyde-Smith of Mississippi, faced his opponent at a debate ahead of this Tuesday’s runoff election, he had to make a choice: confront Ms. Hyde-Smith over her comments about attending “a public hanging,” which evoked the state’s racist history, or take a milder approach to avoid alienating the conservative-leaning white voters who will most likely decide the election.

articles.headline: Marijuana Legalization Threatens These Dogs’ Collars
articles.snippet: Drug-sniffing dogs that are trained to detect marijuana are complicating searches where pot has been legalized. That’s forcing some into early retirement.
articles.abstract: Drug-sniffing dogs that are trained to detect marijuana are complicating searches where pot has been legalized. That’s forcing some into early retirement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Officer Tulo will turn in his badge in January, forced into early retirement by the country’s waning war on weed.

articles.headline: E.U. Leaders and U.K. Agree on Brexit Divorce Terms
articles.snippet: The settlement reached at a summit meeting on Sunday must pass votes in the British Parliament, and leaves deep uncertainties about Britain’s future.
articles.abstract: The settlement reached at a summit meeting on Sunday must pass votes in the British Parliament, and leaves deep uncertainties about Britain’s future.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — More than four decades after Britain tied itself to its Continental neighbors, Prime Minister Theresa May obtained the approval of the other 27 European Union members on a formal divorce pact from the bloc, a consequential step intended to take the country on a new, if unclear, path.
articles.byline: By Stephen Castle and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: China’s Tactic to Catch a Fugitive Official: Hold His Two American Children
articles.snippet: The Chinese police are barring Victor and Cynthia Liu from leaving China in an effort to force their father to return. U.S. officials object to the growing practice of an “exit ban.”
articles.abstract: The Chinese police are barring Victor and Cynthia Liu from leaving China in an effort to force their father to return. U.S. officials object to the growing practice of an “exit ban.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Victor and Cynthia Liu landed with their mother on a tropical Chinese island in June to visit an ailing grandfather, they thought they would soon be on a plane back to their East Coast lives — he to start his sophomore year at Georgetown University, and she to work at the consulting firm McKinsey & Company in New York.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong and Michael Forsythe

articles.headline: The New TV Season: Reboots and Reality Shows Are Sinking. Fallon Counters a Move by Colbert.
articles.snippet: Elsewhere in the network landscape, Dick Wolf proves he still has the ratings touch, and audiences rediscover the medical drama.
articles.abstract: Elsewhere in the network landscape, Dick Wolf proves he still has the ratings touch, and audiences rediscover the medical drama.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two months into the new television season, there’s big ratings news: The N.F.L. is back!

articles.headline: How Cheap Labor Drives China’s A.I. Ambitions
articles.snippet: If China is the Saudi Arabia of data, its data factories are the refineries, turning raw data into the fuel that can power China’s goal of A.I. supremacy.
articles.abstract: If China is the Saudi Arabia of data, its data factories are the refineries, turning raw data into the fuel that can power China’s goal of A.I. supremacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some of the most critical work in advancing China’s technology goals takes place in a former cement factory in the middle of the country’s heartland, far from the aspiring Silicon Valleys of Beijing and Shenzhen. An idled concrete mixer still stands in the middle of the courtyard. Boxes of melamine dinnerware are stacked in a warehouse next door.

articles.headline: For the First Time, a Black Woman Will Lead The Harvard Crimson
articles.snippet: Kristine E. Guillaume, of Queens, made it through a rigorous process to take charge of a student publication once run by Franklin D. Roosevelt.
articles.abstract: Kristine E. Guillaume, of Queens, made it through a rigorous process to take charge of a student publication once run by Franklin D. Roosevelt.
articles.lead_paragraph: Writers and editors at The Harvard Crimson have gone on to be presidents (John F. Kennedy, Franklin D. Roosevelt), tech billionaires (Steve Ballmer, the former chief executive of Microsoft), news media bosses (Jeff Zucker, the head of CNN) and a number of my colleagues at The New York Times. But what the newspaper had in power, it lacked in diversity.

articles.headline: Migrants in Tijuana Run to U.S. Border, but Fall Back in Face of Tear Gas
articles.snippet: A peaceful march veered out of control as hundreds of migrants tried to evade a Mexican police blockade and reach the border crossing.
articles.abstract: A peaceful march veered out of control as hundreds of migrants tried to evade a Mexican police blockade and reach the border crossing.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIJUANA, Mexico — A peaceful march by Central American migrants waiting at the southwestern United States border veered out of control on Sunday afternoon, as hundreds of people tried to evade a Mexican police blockade and run toward a giant border crossing that leads into San Diego.
articles.byline: By Maya Averbuch and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: After a Wildfire, Rebuilding Life Can Be Hardest for the Oldest
articles.snippet: Many who fled the flames ravaging Paradise, Calif., were retirees with health problems and few resources. “Half of them don’t have it in them to start all over again,” a nursing supervisor at a shelter said.
articles.abstract: Many who fled the flames ravaging Paradise, Calif., were retirees with health problems and few resources. “Half of them don’t have it in them to start all over again,” a nursing supervisor at a shelter said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICO, Calif. — The deadliest and most destructive wildfire in California history, the Camp Fire, was finally brought under control by firefighters on Sunday after raging for 17 days. But for many people left homeless by the fire, the most frightening part of the disaster is just beginning.

articles.headline: $3,700 Generators and $666 Sinks: FEMA Contractors Charged Steep Markups on Puerto Rico Repairs
articles.snippet: FEMA is spending more than $1 billion on emergency repairs to homes in Puerto Rico damaged by Hurricane Maria, but much of it is going to contractors charging steep markups and overhead.
articles.abstract: FEMA is spending more than $1 billion on emergency repairs to homes in Puerto Rico damaged by Hurricane Maria, but much of it is going to contractors charging steep markups and overhead.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — Juan F. Rodríguez had substantial damage to his house in northeastern Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria slammed through in September 2017, but he felt better when he was told that the Federal Emergency Management Agency would pay for $5,000 in repairs.

articles.headline: G.M. to Idle Plants and Cut Thousands of Jobs as Sales Slow
articles.snippet: The automaker said the moves would affect five factories in the United States and Canada. President Trump said he was unhappy with the move.
articles.abstract: The automaker said the moves would affect five factories in the United States and Canada. President Trump said he was unhappy with the move.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors announced Monday that it planned to idle five factories in North America and cut roughly 14,000 jobs in a bid to trim costs. It was a jarring reflection of the auto industry’s adjustment to changing consumer tastes and sluggish sales.
